docs.title: Armadillo Local Quickstart Setup
docs.text:
Welcome! This guide shows how to run Armadillo, RServer, and Keycloak locally with Docker Compose.

Note

The preferred way to install Armadillo in production is via systemd. Feel free to use our docker setup.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Docker
  • Docker Compose
  • Git

docs.title: Quickstart
docs.text:
Clone this repository:

git clone https://github.com/molgenis/molgenis-service-armadillo.git
cd molgenis-service-armadillo/docker/quickstart

Start the stack

docker compose up

This starts:

  • Armadillo → http://localhost:8000
  • Keycloak → http://localhost:8080 (admin console)
  • RServer → localhost:6311

Logs and data are stored in ./logs and ./data.

docs.title: Host File Setup
docs.text: For local development, the services need to resolve each other by hostname. We recommend adding the following entries to your hosts file.

docs.title: Linux / macOS
docs.text:
Edit /etc/hosts with sudo:

sudo nano /etc/hosts

add these lines: 

127.0.0.1   armadillo
127.0.0.1   keycloak
127.0.0.1   rserver

docs.title: Windows
docs.text:
• open notepad as Administrator
  • Open the file: 
    C:\Windows\System32\drivers\etc\hosts

Add the following lines:

127.0.0.1   armadillo
127.0.0.1   keycloak
127.0.0.1   rserver

docs.title: Verify
docs.text:
ping keycloak

you should see it resolve to 127.0.0.1

docs.title: Why?
docs.text:
• Armadillo config expects to talk to http://keycloak:8080
  • Keycloak redirects back to http://armadillo:8080
  • RServer is contacted by Armadillo at http://rserver:6311

docs.title: Keycloak Setup
docs.text:
After starting with docker compose up, Keycloak is available at:

  • Admin console: http://localhost:8080
  • Login credentials: admin / admin

docs.title: Import Realm
docs.text: The repo provides a realm config under ./keycloak/realms. It is automatically imported on startup.

docs.title: Add a Test User
docs.text:
1. Open the Keycloak Admin Console
  2. Go to Realms → Armadillo
  3. Go to Users → Add User
  4. Username: demo@example.org
  5. Email verified: ✅
  6. Go to Credentials → Set Password
  7. Password: demo12345
  8. Temporary: OFF

docs.title: Armadillo Configuration
docs.text:
1. Add the previously added user in keycloak also to Armadillo
  2. Add a project
  3. Connect as a researcher to the service. Use http://localhost:8000 as the Armadillo URL.

docs.title: Keycloak healthcheck fails
docs.text: • Ensure port 9000 is free on your system (used for readiness checks).

docs.title: [invalid_user_info_response] 403 Forbidden
docs.text: • Confirm that the user exists in Keycloak and has a password set. This user also needs to be added to Armadillo.

docs.title: Reset stack
docs.text:
docker compose down -v
docker compose up --build

docs.title: Kubernetes
docs.text: We have helm charts available for Kubernetes setup. Profiles are maintained bij DataShield. We have helm charts available in our private repository. If you need help or want to contribute please give us a message via support@molgenis.org or you can find us in the #Armadillo-support Slack channel

docs.title: Armadillo installation
docs.text:
Note

This guide assumes you are using Ubuntu Server LTS, the installation script expects the systemd service. See Install alternatives below.

docs.title: Server resources
docs.text:
You need a server or virtual machine to deploy the Armadillo stack. The specifications of the resource are the following, depending on the participant size of the cohort you are running.

Participants Memory (in GB) Diskspace (in GB) CPU cores 0-20.000 8 100 4 20.000-70.000 16 100 4 70.000 > 32 150 8

In case of using dsOmics this setup can be rather bigger. Please contact us for the latest specifications.

docs.title: Software requirements
docs.text:
• Java 21 JRE or JDK
  • Docker

In addition to these, there are other optional components you may wish to install, such as setting up nginx as a reverse proxy.

docs.title: Domain
docs.text:
A domain or an hostname ie cohort.armadillo.domain.org is required to run Armadillo.

This domain is needed for the installation script.

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text: Before deploying Armadillo, you need to register the domain that your Armadillo instance will use with an authentication server. This ensures that users can securely sign in and that authorization decisions (who can access what) remain under the control of the Data Manager within your Armadillo installation.

docs.title: Supported Authentication Providers
docs.text:
Armadillo supports integration with different OpenID Connect (OIDC)–compatible authentication servers, such as:

  • Keycloak
  • FusionAuth
  • Other OIDC-compliant identity providers (e.g. Azure AD, Google Identity, etc.)

docs.title: Example: Local Keycloak Setup
docs.text:
If you want to run Armadillo locally or test your deployment, you can use the Keycloak + Armadillo quick setup provided in our Docker setup.

You’ll find an example in our documentation, which starts both Keycloak and Armadillo and automatically configures OIDC integration.

docs.title: Registering with a consortium authentication server (DataSHIELD)
docs.text: If your organization is part of a consortium that offers a shared authentication server (for example the DataSHIELD authentication server), you can register your Armadillo domain with them. This delegates authentication and user management to the central server while your Data Manager continues to control authorization inside Armadillo.

docs.title: What to send when registering
docs.text:
Send an email to the consortium contact (or support@example.org if you use our central contact) containing:

  • The domain(s) for your Armadillo instance (e.g. armadillo.example.org)
  • The email address of the Data Manager who should receive admin permissions
  • A note that you want to register for the DataSHIELD authentication server
  • (Optional) Which project you belong to (e.g. LIFECYCLE, ATHLETE, LONGITOOLS)

After processing, you will receive the details you need to configure Armadillo, typically:

  • OIDC Service URL (example: https://lifecycle-auth.molgenis.org)
  • OIDC Client ID
  • OIDC Client Secret

These values are then inserted into your deployment configuration (see step 2.p in the deployment guide).

docs.title: Securing the connection
docs.text:
You need a SSL certificate to configuring the front-end proxy and make the browser use https before putting data on the server.

If SELinux is enabled, run the following command to ensure that the application can connect to required services:

setsebool -P httpd_can_network_connect on

docs.title: Installing Armadillo as service
docs.text: We run Armadillo in production as a Linux service on Ubuntu, ensuring it gets restarted when the server is rebooted. You might be able to reproduce also on CentOS (using yum instead of apt).

docs.title: 1. Install necessary software
docs.text:
apt update
apt install openjdk-21-jre-headless
apt install docker.io
Note

you might need to execute these commands as sudo

docs.title: 2. Run installation script
docs.text:
This step will install the latest release.

After installation the Armadillo application is installed with the given configuration and its service.

docs.title: 2.1 Download the setup script
docs.text:
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/molgenis/molgenis-service-armadillo/master/scripts/install/armadillo-setup.sh

Or manually download the setup script via right click on this link (Right mouse 'save as')

Make sure armadillo-setup.sh is executable using

chmod u+x armadillo-setup.sh

The installation script requires some arguments:

Argument Application admin-user Local armadillo admin user admin-password Secure password for the admin user datadir The location where the data is stored. This directory should be have enough diskspace en could be backuped (Default → /usr/share/armadillo/data) domain The URL where armadillo is listening on. For example: cohort.armadillo.domain.org oidc Enable OIDC, see authentication oidc_url Given oidc URL oidc_clientid Given client ID oidc_clientsecret Given secret ID

docs.title: 2.2 Run the install script
docs.text:
Adapt the following install command to suit your situation. Use --help to see all options.

Note

https://lifecycle-auth.molgenis.org is MOLGENIS provider of the OIDC service but you can also use your own.

bash armadillo-setup.sh \
    --admin-user admin \
    --admin-password xxxxx 
    --domain armadillo.cohort.study.com \
    --oidc \
    --oidc_url https://lifecycle-auth.molgenis.org \
    --oidc_clientid clientid \
    --oidc_clientsecret secret \

docs.title: File locations
docs.text:
The script creates using default values the follow files and directories:

ls /etc/armadillo/application.yml
ls /etc/systemd/system/armadillo.service
ls /usr/share/armadillo/*
ls /var/log/armadillo/*

docs.title: Controlling the Armadillo service
docs.text:
systemctl status armadillo

systemctl stop armadillo

systemctl start armadillo

After the installation is complete Armadillo is listening on port 8080. Test the setup by visiting http://armadillo.cohort.study.com:8080 or type in the terminal wget http://localhost:8080 to see a text response.

Note

The Armadillo website is not secure yet so you need to setup a front-end proxy.

When having setup this front-end proxy you could get a bad gateway (see below). This mostly means Armadillo is not ready yet as you already have tested armadillo as mentioned above.

502 Bad Gateway
nginx/1.18.0 (Ubuntu)

Recheck with wget http://localhost:8080 and check the log files.

docs.title: Setting up Proxy Server
docs.text:
We highly recommend using nginx with MolgenisArmadillo. We use the follow configuration located in /etc/nginx/sites-available/armadillo.conf

server {
  listen 80;
  server_name armadillo.cohort.study.com
  include /etc/nginx/conf.d/*.conf;
  location / {
  proxy_pass http://localhost:8080;
  client_max_body_size 0;
  proxy_read_timeout 600s;
  proxy_redirect http://localhost:8080/ $scheme://$host/;
  proxy_set_header Host $host;
  proxy_http_version 1.1;
  }
}
Note

The above is still not secure but not you can reach Armadillo from http://armadillo.cohort.study.com.

To secure the communication using https we have a nginx example

docs.title: Backups
docs.text: A good start for data backup is the /usr/share/armadillo and /etc/armadillo. If you gave another datadir as setup option you also should backup this directory. For disaster backups you should contact your IT department.

docs.title: Metrics
docs.text:
The Spring Boot Actuator endpoint is by default open to all authenticated users (the health and info endpoint are open to all). To allow for monitoring as well, we added the possibility of configuring an api-token that will give access to the actuator endpoint without logging in otherwise. To configure this api key, an addition will have to be made to the application.yml of Armadillo (just like how the local admin user and password are configured): 

armadillo:
  api-key: my-secret-api-key
After configuring this, the endpoint can be reached: 
curl 'http://localhost:8080/actuator/prometheus' -i -X GET \ v
 -H 'Accept: text/plain' --header 'X-API-KEY: my-secret-api-key'

The endpoint will still be available via basicauth and oauth as well, either logging in and then accessing via the browser or by passing Authorization headers with the correct authorization details.

You can use this in your monitoring application like prometheus. (Config example for prometheus) 

scrape_configs:
  - job_name: 'my-armadillo-app'
    metrics_path: '/actuator/prometheus'
    static_configs:
      - targets: ['armadilo.url-example.com:8080']

docs.title: Disable or restrict Metrics
docs.text: Spring Boot Actuator is accessible for all users in our project (including /actuator/metrics). Below are ways to disable or restrict it.

docs.title: 1. Disable Metrics
docs.text:
To remove /actuator/metrics from HTTP exposure, add this to application.yml:

management:
  endpoints:
    web:
      exposure:
        exclude: metrics
  • ✅ Other endpoints (like /actuator/health, /actuator/info) remain available
  • ❌ /actuator/metrics returns 404 Not Found

If you want to disable all metrics collection (Micrometer), add:

management:
  metrics:
    enable:
      all: false

docs.title: 2. Restrict Metrics: Nginx as a Reverse Proxy
docs.text:
At the infrastructure level, you can block or whitelist IPs for Actuator endpoints.

location /actuator/metrics {
    allow 192.168.1.0/24;   # whitelist internal network
    deny all;               # block others
    proxy_pass http://localhost:8080/actuator/metrics;
}

location /actuator/ {
    proxy_pass http://localhost:8080/actuator/;
}

docs.title: Install alternatives
docs.text:
• On local machine using java
  • Armadillo running as a Docker container.
  • Apache

docs.title: What's next?
docs.text:
• For the server owner or data manager who need to put data on to the server
  • For the researcher who want to start analyzing the data on the server

docs.title: Apache
docs.text: It is possible to run Molgenis Armadillo using Apache, however we do not provide support with this configuration.

docs.title: Encoding
docs.text:
Apache requires some additional configuration to get the /storage/projects/{project}/objects/{object} to work. When this endpoint doesn't work:

- tables cannot be assigned
- subsets cannot be created
- resources cannot be used.

docs.title: Tell Armadillo about https
docs.text: We need to tell Armadillo server how to building URLs.

docs.title: Changes to your site-enabled configuration
docs.text:
Your configuration probably should look like this.

ProxyPreserveHost On

ProxyPass / http://localhost:8080/ nocanon

AllowEncodedSlashes On

RequestHeader set X-Forwarded-Proto https
RequestHeader set X-Forwarded-Port 443

After setting this don't forget to restart Apache.

docs.title: Armadillo management
docs.text: Armadillo has three main screens to manage projects, user access and DataSHIELD profiles:

docs.title: Create data access projects
docs.text: Data managers can use the Armadillo web user interface or MolgenisArmadillo R client to create 'projects' and upload their data into those. Data tables need to be in parquet format that supports fast selections of the columns (variables) you need for analysis. Other files can be configured as 'resources'.

docs.title: Manage user access
docs.text: Data managers can use the permission screen to give email addresses access to the data. Everybody signs in via single sign on using an OIDC central authentication server such as KeyCloack or Fusion auth that federates to authentication systems of connected institutions, ideally using a federated AAI such as LifeScience AAI.

docs.title: Configure DataSHIELD profiles
docs.text: To analyse data, users must choose a datashield profile. Armadillo owners can use the web user interface to configure new profiles. Assuming you installed docker you can also start/stop these images. Alternatively you can use docker-compose for that. We recommend selecting one of the DataSHIELD standard profiles.

docs.title: End users can use Armadillo as any other DataSHIELD server
docs.text: A researcher connects from an R client to one or multiple Armadillo servers. The data is loaded into an R session on the Armadillo server specifically created for the researcher. Analysis requests are sent to the R session on each Armadillo server. There the analysis is performed and aggregated results are sent back to the client.

docs.title: Migrate Armadillo 2 to Armadillo 3
docs.text: Migrating from Armadillo 2 to Armadillo 3 can be done in two variants, a full migration including projects, users and data or just projects and their users. Both options require Python (version 3.8) and additional python libraries, described in Getting started.

docs.title: Getting started
docs.text: To start the migration, python 3.8 is advised together with a number of utilitarian python libraries. Other python versions might work, but performance has only been tested with python 3.8.

docs.title: Install with Python virtual environment
docs.text:
For more info see python virtual environment.

The following code does not require superuser rights. The code does assume you are already in the scripts/upgrade directory.

python3 -m venv venv
source ./venv/bin/activate
pip install -r requirements.txt
Tip

If the installation of one (or more libraries) fails, try to install the libraries one by one.

docs.title: 1. Check if there's enough space left on the server
docs.text:
df -h

Compare to:

du -h /var/lib/minio
Warning

Available space should be at least twice the size of the MinIO folder.

docs.title: 2. Backup Armadillo 2 settings
docs.text:
mkdir armadillo2-backup 
rsync -avr /usr/share/armadillo armadillo2-backup 
cp /etc/armadillo/application.yml armadillo2-backup/application-armadillo2.yml
Note

Change /usr/share to the path matching your local config.

docs.title: 3. Install helper software
docs.text:
FIXME: Skip these steps as you have already done installing the python code in a virtual env.

Login to your server as root, using ssh.

apt update

#apt install pip
#pip install minio
#pip install fusionauth-client
#pip install simple_term_menu

If you get a purple message asking to update, accept and install everything.

Restart of server is recommended after this.

Note

The commands in this manual are for Ubuntu, on other linux systems, the apt command needs to be replaced with the correct one.

docs.title: 4. Stop all docker images for Armadillo 2
docs.text:
List all docker images

docker ps -a

Stop and remove all Armadillo 2 related images (except for MinIO), e.g.

docker rm armadillo_auth_1 armadillo_console_1 armadillo_rserver-default_1 armadillo_rserver-mediation_1 armadillo_rserver-exposome_1 armadillo_rserver-omics_1 armadillo_armadillo_1 -f

Check with docker ps -a if there are still containers running, if so remove these (except for the MinIO) in the same way as the others.

Warning

Make sure you do not remove the docker instance of MinIO before you migrated the data!

docs.title: 5. Install armadillo
docs.text:
apt update
apt install openjdk-19-jre-headless
apt install docker.io

The docker.io step might fail because containerd already exists, if that's the case, remove containerd and try again:

apt remove containerd.io
apt install docker.io

Get armadillo:

wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/molgenis/molgenis-service-armadillo/master/scripts/install/armadillo-setup.sh 
bash armadillo-setup.sh \
    --admin-user admin \
    --admin-password xxxxx 
    --domain my.server.com \
    --oidc \
    --oidc_url https://lifecycle-auth.molgenis.org \
    --oidc_clientid clientid \
    --oidc_clientsecret secret \
    --cleanup \

Don't forget to set a proper admin password (use a generator), domain, clientid and clientsecret. The client id and secret can be found on the lifecycle auth server in the configuration for your server. If you don't have permissions to receive this, you can ask the support team to get it for you.

Open armadillo in the browser and try to login using basicauth to check if the server is running properly. If it is not running at all, try:

systemctl start armadillo

docs.title: 6. Export data from Armadillo 2 into armadillo 3
docs.text:
Look up the user/password in the application.yml of the old armadillo. They are called MinIO access key and minio secret key.

cat /root/armadillo2-backup/application-armadillo2.yml

Do the following step in a separate screen. On ubuntu use:

screen

Navigate to the armadillo folder:

cd /usr/share/armadillo

This step will copy Armadillo 2 data from minio into the folder matching of an Armadillo 3 data folder:

mkdir data
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/molgenis/molgenis-service-armadillo/master/scripts/upgrade/migrate-minio.py
python3 migrate-minio.py  --minio http://localhost:9000 --target /usr/share/armadillo/data

This might take a couple of minutes. You can detach the screen using Ctrl+A followed by D and reattach it using screen -r.

docs.title: 7. Run Armadillo 3 using exported data
docs.text:
Make sure to move the exported data into the new 'data' folder. Optionally you might need to fix user permissions, e.g.:

chown armadillo:armadillo -R data

Check if armadillo is running by going to the URL of your server in the browser, login and navigate to the projects tab.

docs.title: 8. Optionally, acquire a permission set from MOLGENIS team
docs.text:
If you previously ran a central authorisation server with MOLGENIS team, they can provide you with procedure to load pre-existing permissions. They will use:

wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/molgenis/molgenis-service-armadillo/master/scripts/upgrade/migrate-auth.py
python3 migrate-auth.py  --fusion-auth https://lifecycle-auth.molgenis.org --armadillo https://thearmadillourl.net

Now check if all users and data are properly migrated.

Note

If the script fails with a timeout, try pinging the armadillo url and lifecycle auth url to see if they're reachable from the server. In case they are not, you could choose to export the users using the export-users.py script locally and then manually enter them into the system.

docs.title: 9. Cleanup ngnix config
docs.text:
Change /etc/nginx/sites-available/armadillo.conf to:

server {
  listen 80;
  server_name urlofyourserver.org
  include /etc/nginx/global.d/*.conf;
  location / {
  proxy_pass http://localhost:8080;
  client_max_body_size 0;
  proxy_read_timeout 600s;
  proxy_redirect http://localhost:8080/ $scheme://$host/;
  proxy_set_header Host $host;
  proxy_http_version 1.1;
  }
}
Note

Note that the https:// is missing in the server_name part.

Note

If port 443 and the SSL certificates are in the old config, you mind have to keep that part, so you should not comment that out. Keep the listen and certificate lines, comment out the rest and paste the config above below the existing config.

Remove the console, auth and storage file from: /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/ and /etc/nginx/sites-available/.

systemctl restart nginx

docs.title: 10. Fix application.yml
docs.text:
Make sure the following is added:

server:
forward-headers-strategy: framework

docs.title: 11. Fix URLs in the lifecycle FusionAuth
docs.text: Add the following to the config of your server: https://yourserver.com/login/oauth2/code/molgenis

docs.title: 12. Set up profiles
docs.text:
Login to armadillo in the browser. Navigate to the "Profiles" tab. Add a new profile with the following properties:

Name: xenon Image: datashield/armadillo-rserver_caravan-xenon:latest Package whitelist: dsBase, resourcer, dsMediation, dsMTLBase, dsSurvival, dsExposome

Assign a random 9-number seed and create and start the container.

docs.title: 13. Remove old MinIO data
docs.text:
First remove the MinIO docker container. First check the name of the container using docker ps -a, then:

docker rm containername -f

After that remove the data:

rm -Rf /var/lib/minio/
Warning

Be sure you have migrated your data successfully or created a backup prior to deleting your minio data folder!

docs.title: Migrate Projects and their users
docs.text:
Migration of just the projects and their users (with their corresponding rights) can be done by using export-users.py and import-users.py.

Warning

This options does not migrate the data!

docs.title: 1. Export Projects and users from Armadillo 2
docs.text:
To export users from an Armadillo 2 server, one must use the export-users.py script. export-users.py can be used by using the following arguments:

  • -f / --fusion-auth (required): The full URL (including http) of the Armadillo 2 server of which you wish to export the Projects and their users from. Please note that export-users.py will prompt to supply the API key for this server once all arguments are valid!
  • -o / --output (required): The output directory in which (unzipped) TSVs will be placed of all projects and their users, with the project name being the TSV name. export-users.py will create a new folder in the supplied output folder named: YYYY-MM-DD, where YYYY is the current year, MM is the current month and DD is the current day.

Again, note that export-users.py will prompt to supply the API key for the -f / --fusion-auth server once all arguments are valid!

Empty projects (without users) will also be exported as an empty TSV (containing only the header). This is a feature that import-users.py, the next step, is able to function with.

Also note that some projects might change in name, as Armadillo 3 is stricter with naming projects.

Example:

pipenv shell
python3 export-users.py -f https://armadillo2-server.org -o ./armadillo_2_exports

docs.title: 2. Import Projects and users TSVs into Armadillo 3
docs.text:
To import users into an Armadillo 3 server, one must use the import-users.py script. import-users can be used by using the following arguments:

  • -s / --server (required): The full URL (including http) of the Armadillo 3 server of which you wish to import the Projects and their users TSVs in step 1. Please note that import-users.py will prompt to supply the API key for this server once all arguments are valid!
  • -d / --user-data (required): The directory, including the folder named after the year-month-day combination, where the export TSVs from step 1 are stored.

Again, note that import-users.py will prompt to supply the API key for the -s / --server server once all arguments are valid!

Empty TSVs from step 1 will be imported as empty projects with no users.

Example:

pipenv shell
python3 import-users.py -s https://armadillo3-server.org -d ./armadillo_2_exports/2023-11-09

docs.title: Migrate Armadillo 3 to Armadillo 4
docs.text:
Upgrade to Armadillo 4 (rock only)

Note

We assume Ubuntu with systemd is used.

The upgrade from Armadillo v3.4 to 4.x is breaking as the profiles must be Rock profiles.

Additionally, when working with an armadillo 4 instance, researchers should update DSMolgenisArmadillo to version 2.0.5 (this version is compatible with armadillo 3 as well).

docs.title: Get latest version
docs.text:
For the latest 4.x release check https://github.com/molgenis/molgenis-service-armadillo/releases/latest. This will redirect to a v4.x.y page.

Make a note of the version as you will use this below.

docs.title: 1. Check your profile types
docs.text:
Check if the new profiles are compatible with your needs, these profile names can be edited later on in the manual:

- datashield/rock-base:latest
- datashield/rock-dolomite-xenon:latest

See also DataSHIELD profiles

docs.title: 2. Check server space
docs.text: Make sure enough disk space is available for the Rock only images.

docs.title: 2.1 Check disk space
docs.text:
# Check disk space
df -H

If you have 15 GB or more available, you can continue. If you have less available, check docker image list to see if you can cleanup some docker images (you only need the latest datashield/armadillo-rserver and datashield/armadillo-rserver_caravan-xenon for armadillo 3).

docs.title: 2.2 Check docker images
docs.text:
First stop all profiles through the Armadillo UI.

Now that the profiles are not running you can delete the old versions of their docker images.

The command are indicative so change as needed.

# should return empty list (i.e. default, xenon, rock)
docker container list

# remove containers not needed
docker container stop <id>
docker container rm <id>

# remove unneeded images/profiles (ie. caravan, ...)
docker image list
docker image rm <id>

If possible download the new images from shell using docker pull beforehand (for minimum downtime):

docker pull datashield/rock-base:latest
docker pull datashield/rock-dolomite-xenon:latest

Check disk space again.

# Check disk space
df -H

docs.title: 3. Download required files
docs.text: Make a note of the version number ie. v4.1.3 as you need to download some files from the terminal using the update script.

docs.title: 3.1 Update script
docs.text:
You need to be root user.

cd /root
# Change the versions number v4.x.y
mkdir v4.x.y
cd v4.x.y

# Check directory location
pwd

# Change the version number v4.x.y then run command
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/molgenis/molgenis-service-armadillo/v4.x.y/scripts/install/armadillo-check-update.sh

Make the script runnable 

chmod u+x armadillo-check-update.sh

docs.title: 3.2 Run update script
docs.text:
You can run the following script to download the new Armadillo version.

Note

The output could help us to help you fix problems.

# Change the version number v4.x.y
./armadillo-check-update.sh 4.x.y

Once the script has completed, you can verify that the Armadillo JAR file has been downloaded by checking the directory:

# See all jar files on your system
ls -ltr /usr/share/armadillo/application/

docs.title: 4.1 application.yml
docs.text:
To compare the latest template to your own configuration, see the troubleshooting section below. The safest way to update armadillo is by fetching the template and filling it in with your configuration using the information in the troubleshooting section. You can try the following first:

Edit the application.yml:

nano /etc/armadillo/application.yml

Below the line docker-management-enabled: true, ensure to insert the line docker-run-in-container: false. Typically, you'll find these configurations at the beginning of the file.

docs.title: 4.2 Make backup of system config
docs.text:
# Still in the correct directory? (`/root/v4.x.y`)
pwd

We make a backup into the same v4.x.y directory but that is not strictly needed.

cp -r /usr/share/armadillo/data/system ./

should result in:

ls system/
# access.json  profiles.json

docs.title: 5. Restart application using new version
docs.text: Armadillo has not yet been updated, follow the following steps to do so:

docs.title: 5.1 Stop Armadillo
docs.text: systemctl stop armadillo

docs.title: 5.2 Link new version
docs.text:
# List application files
ls -l /usr/share/armadillo/application/

# Remove the linked file
rm /usr/share/armadillo/application/armadillo.jar

# Attach new linked file and dont forget to change the version number v4.x.y
ln -s /usr/share/armadillo/application/armadillo-4.x.y.jar /usr/share/armadillo/application/armadillo.jar

# Check result
ls -l /usr/share/armadillo/application/

docs.title: 5.3 Restart Armadillo
docs.text:
systemctl start armadillo
systemctl status armadillo

docs.title: 6. Log on to the UI
docs.text: Go to your armadillo website. Is the version in the left top corner updated? This means the update was successful.

docs.title: 7. Update profiles
docs.text:
Login into the website and go to the profiles tab. Here two profiles should be listed: default and xenon. Any other profiles can be removed.

  1. Edit the default profile.
  2. Change the "image" to datashield/rock-base:latest and save.
  3. Start the default profile.
  4. Edit the "xenon" profile.
  5. Change the "image" to datashield/rock-dolomite-xenon:latest and save.
  6. Start the xenon profile.

Everything should now be working correctly. You can try and login to your server via the central analysis server, using the DSMolgenisArmadillo (2.0.5 or up) package to test.

docs.title: Logs
docs.text:
Reviewing the log files can provide valuable insights into any issues or activities within the application. If you encounter any errors or unexpected behavior, examining the log files can often help diagnose the problem.

Check log files location

ls -l /var/log/armadillo/

should look something like:

-rw-r--r-- 1 root      root      111224 Jan 30 11:47 armadillo.log
-rw-r--r-- 1 armadillo armadillo  68872 Jan 30 11:47 audit.log
-rw-r--r-- 1 root      root        8428 Dec 19 11:57 error.log

If the error.log data/time is around current day/time you have to check this file.

# See last 100 lines
tail -n 100 /var/log/armadillo/error.log

Otherwise, you can look into armadillo.log:

# See last 100 lines
tail -n 100 /var/log/armadillo/armadillo.log

or

# Follow all files for changes (keep open to see activities)
tail -f /var/log/armadillo/*

docs.title: Compare application.yml
docs.text:
Although we try to be very complete in this manual, if you run into issues, it might be because a setting was changed in the application.yml. You can check if application settings has any new entries by first downloading the application template (for reference).

# Change the version number v4.x.y
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/molgenis/molgenis-service-armadillo/v4.x.y/application.template.yml

To see the difference run:

diff --side-by-side /etc/armadillo/application.yml application.template.yml

Your output should look like output below.

  • Left side column is your settings.
  • Right side column is our expected settings.
  • In the middle some symbols may occur:
  • the < means only your settings
  • the > means we have a setting (probably added or options)
  • the | means both have different values which happens with OICD/oauth settings for sure.
armadillo:                            armadillo:
  # set this false if you DON'T want Armadillo to create/edit      # set this false if you DON'T want Armadillo to create/edit
  docker-management-enabled: true                  docker-management-enabled: true
....
audit:                                  <
  log:                                  <
    path: /var/log/armadillo/audit.log  <
                                        <
....

storage:                                         storage:
  ## to change location of the data storage        ## to change location of the data storage
  root-dir: /usr/share/armadillo/data           |  root-dir: data

Making changes may be a little tricky. You can backup

cp /etc/armadillo/application.yml ./
# list files
ls .

then edit

nano /etc/armadillo/application.yml

docs.title: Migrate Armadillo 4 to Armadillo 5
docs.text: MOLGENIS Armadillo v5.x.y depends on Java 21, support for all older versions of Java are dropped, so if your Armadillo instance is not running on Java 21 yet, you'll have to update. To do so:

docs.title: 1. Get the update script
docs.text:
cd /root
# Change the versions number v5.x.y
mkdir v5.x.y
cd v5.x.y

# Change the version number v5.x.y then run command
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/molgenis/molgenis-service-armadillo/v5.x.y/scripts/install/armadillo-check-update.sh

Make the script runnable 

chmod u+x armadillo-check-update.sh

docs.title: 2. Run the update script
docs.text:
# Change the version number v5.x.y
./armadillo-check-update.sh 5.x.y

Once the script has completed, you can verify that the Armadillo JAR file has been downloaded by checking the directory:

# See all jar files on your system
ls -ltr /usr/share/armadillo/application/

docs.title: 3. Make backup of system config
docs.text:
# Still in the correct directory? (`/root/v5.x.y`)
pwd

We make a backup into the same v5x.y directory but that is not strictly needed.

cp -r /usr/share/armadillo/data/system ./

ls system/
# access.json  profiles.json

docs.title: 4. Stop Armadillo
docs.text: systemctl stop armadillo

docs.title: 5. Update Java
docs.text:
apt update
apt install openjdk-21-jre-headless

docs.title: 6. Link new version
docs.text:
# List application files
ls -l /usr/share/armadillo/application/

# Remove the linked file
rm /usr/share/armadillo/application/armadillo.jar

# Attach new linked file and dont forget to change the version number v5.x.y
ln -s /usr/share/armadillo/application/armadillo-5.x.y.jar /usr/share/armadillo/application/armadillo.jar

# Check result
ls -l /usr/share/armadillo/application/

docs.title: 7 Restart Armadillo
docs.text:
systemctl start armadillo
systemctl status armadillo
